comments.commentBody: Seriously Seth Kugel? This is the NYTimes, how can you recommend Hooks Hut?  Have you even been there?  It was the worst meal I've had in years, you can't even really call that jerk chicken. I guess I can give you the benefit of the doubt being that the article was written three years ago, maybe it was better then, but to anyone going to Curacao, avoid this place at all costs.  I don't know what was worse the loud disco music coming from the bar next door or low volume Bryan Adams live cd they were playing at the restaurant.  Do not go there!!!!!!

I found SFJ blog about a 8 months ago. At first I wasn't really sure what he was trying to do. Then I just let it happen and enjoyed the variety of photos he posted. I think not always knowing what was actually in the picture added to the enjoyment. You could see something different each time.

I have been taken at least a photo a day with my iPhone since July. It has made me look for and see things on my daily commute in a different way. Sometimes the results aren't great, they are "barely" photography. But often, they are beautiful, to me.

Thanks SFJ for the inspiration.
Will somebody fire Jim Gray and put a competent reporter and interviewer in his place?
My best wishes to Clint Mathis, his goal in WC2002 still bring a smile to my face. Thank you for all the good memories!

It was a dark and stormy night....

I figure that everyone's entitle to "blow it" occasionally including Moseley -- who's otherwise been quite effective filling in for the gap left by Andy's DL absence.

And with Andy seemingly on a slow track in terms of mending -- Moseley will still have a few more shots to make his case for sticking around after the 40-man roster kicks in.

The race is indeed a tight one and the we need guys like Moseley to be able to step into the breach when the need arises. So here's hoping he not only watches those tapes -- but learns from what he sees.

Walt is not on vacation.

He simply saw no need whatsoever to comment on this utterly non-story.

Most of what we now call terrorism stems from blowback generated from dumb policies and actions of our own government going back decades.

This is Vietnam writ large...and no matter how many trillions we spend and/or millions we kill.....this trajectory leads us into the ditch.
They don't want us there and frankly they can kill each other and live in their misable countries.  If they attack us, we nuke them.  Simple

I repeat:

Gentlemen don't read each other's mail.

Re-read Machiavelli on mercenaries.

Whether left, right, or middle, every President apparently bows down to the military and those who profit from making military weapons. How can the U.S. justify fighting in 12 countries, while the economy is tanking, while our schools are failing, while are roads and electric grid are becoming obsolete, etc...?!?!?!?!?!?!?! We're fighting tiny groups with AK-47's and maybe RPG's with drones, clandestine operation forces, fighter planes, tanks, and we keep losing...These wars are assuring that generations of people will continually hate the U.S. and continue to attack us indefinitely...We most assuredly will never win this fight and the age of American Empire has ended with a whimper in Iraq and Afghanistan...These 12 other wars are for show...

"So sad... an endless war to fill the coffers of the military industrial complex."--Scotchguard, Denver

Exactly!

And that explains why this course of action is being pursued despite the fact that, according to historical research, "these operations seldom achieve either their military or political objectives."

"One of these days...America is going to have to grow up and start dealing with the root causes of what turns desperate impoverished young men into Freedom Fighters...."--TritonPSH, LVNV

Correct, but not going to happen, and here is why: The military-industrial-congressional complex of the US (MICCUS) does not want the hostilities ever to end. Perpetual war is the preferred alternative.

The War on Terror is like the War on Drugs and the War on Illegal Immigration: millions of Americans derive their livelihoods from these wars. To cite just one example: If you are a schoolteacher and you know that one-half your students have parents who've entered the country illegally, it is going to be VERY difficult for you to support putting an end to illegal immigration.

#112
look at this way, for every million we spend to kill one terrorist, we are creating ten more terrorists from the civilian deaths that we also cause. So its technically costing only $100,000 to create a new terrorist, a much better return on money.

Good to see the Obama administration following the strategy formulated by Secretary Rumsfeld and his DoD team as outlined in Douglas Feith's "War and Decision". This multi-state asymmetric attack is to keep the enemy off balance to limit their ability to plan and organize attacks on the USA. As Mr. Rumsfeld said,"When they are looking for a safe place to sleep, they are not planning missions."

One suggestion: Put a team into Sweden and dismantle Wikileaks, apprehend the leadership and staff, identify the leakers and try them for treason or declare them combatants and send to Gitmo.

It appears to be an effective and cheap strategy for dealing with extremists. Minimal collateral damage (compared to heavy mechanized warfare), maximum fear for our enemies, and mostly thin air for the press to manipulate. Sounds like the future of warfare in the Internet age.

Many in the comment section found this news is a Pentagon adulation.

OK so what is alternative invading countries and showing in the TV's hot fire so you can proof that you are really killing terrorists.

The day one GWB declared war to IRAQ, I thought it is wrong, war on terror can sometimes waged by hot fire but mainly and profoundly should wage with this kind of activity, Not open fire.

As we see in commentators, this news , or at least the the news it self was depreciated as a method,they are lying us.may be.but when we are hot firing on those Afghnais and Iraqis we are really provocating the hornet nest nothing else.

Waging fight on terror cannot be pure hot fire, intelligence and special operations is key to find and destroy key targets as i was suggesting back in 2003. Visible blood and flesh besides the images of occupying forces is beefing up that terror demons.

Yes I feel safe, this the style we were using in cold war, silent behind the curtain but effective.

Obama = Bush.
The new boss is the same as the old boss.

can the leftist base of Obama finally accept there is an actual threat and that our actions since 9/11 are dealing with people who wish to topple the USA? #3
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
What utter nonsense. Do you seriously think that those of us on the left think there's no threat? What we refuse to accept is your hero Bush lying us into a war in Iraq that has cost this country thousands of lives and billions of dollars, and getting us mired in Afghanistan with no long-term plan for an exit strategy. While you've delude yourself that the fight against terrorists can be won through conventional warfare, those of us on the left have always asserted that terrorism can only be defeated through intelligence, covert actions and very specific and narrow targets. A notion that candidate John Kerry was widely ridiculed about from the right and of which he of course was correct. It's about time you came around to the right way of thinking about things.
yes this confirms a secure, happy, prosperous person translating into a healthier economy....remember,'one is happier and more secure with money'

What is it that will satisfy you people?
You oppose the war, and now you oppose any sort of operation.
To prevent radicalism there should be a long term policy, there is no doubt in that. But until that policy works which will take years and decades, the matter of fact is that there remain some terrorists who do acts of terrorism. Now whether you want to color them with love or whatever you prefer, the government can't lie down and wait for the long term policy to work.
If you have any other short term alternative please mention.
It's always fascinating to see how wildly at odds with each other readers' opinions are, given that they are commenting on the same "data."

It is mind boggling America is still okay with stuff like this. Especially, those on the left who hated Bush for starting wars, and are now fine with Obama bombing who ever under the name of counterterrorism (which just to clarify I dislike Bush and Obama equally). This strategy of propping up unpopular dictators in the name of America safety or spreading democracy is the reason there is terrorism. Do a little research on Iran, Nicaragua, Chile, Pakistan, Iraq, Panama, Brazil, Dominican Republic, Bolivia, Haiti, and Indonesia just to name the worst. The people of Yemen will eventually fully support Al Qaeda because they will decide the jihadist are on their side and America is on the side of the Yemen government that they view as oppressive.
wow.... i love our country, but should we be expanding our 'war on terrorism' while it has failed so horribly everywhere else?? what are we doing?

still not enough. we must spend more money and transfer more military into these areas that promote terror. american military presence in the mideast must never have a timetable for exiting. whatever it takes to remove this threat of terror the u.s. must do. as for enlisting the aid of other nations, remember, if you want a job done right--do it yourself.

1 million dollars for each solider a year plus all the mistakes and lost truck loads of money etc etc This is the real war on America. We are sinking in debt, the job front is terrible, wages are shrinking, foreclosures are up oh yeah a couple of people supply the war are making huge profits and about the only secrets out there are plans to get us out of this mess. But then they know how to a secret.... they aren't any plans.
This is scary!
